Description: Glazed composition seal-stone (?), with the base cut straight, the top tapered, rounded and perforated horizontally for suspension. The horizontal cross-section would be rectangular if the edges had not been bevelled off. The base bears the representation of a long-curve-horned ibex, facing right, with a large lotus flower decorating its chest, and a longer-stemmed lotus flower behind it.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, "Qasr", east annex (C), chamber 2 or 3
Curator's comments: "Engraved porcelain" seal-stone "of Syrian type", "found in the Kasr", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 74 § 70, p. 111, pl. xli, 73, found "in chamber 2 or 3" (ibid., p. 74 § 72). See also London, BM, EA 18485 and Boston, MFA 87.710, 87.711, unfinished and unengraved.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 74 § 70, 72, p. 111, pl. xli, 73)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.40, p.45, p.67, p.182, pl.24)
